importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the latest update on Sir David Attenborough's achievement as the oldest Daytime Emmy winner, highlighting a significant milestone in his career and in television award history.
The year 2024 is referenced as when Dick Van Dyke previously held the record for the oldest Daytime Emmy winner, providing context for Sir David's record-breaking achievement in 2025.
The 52nd annual Daytime Emmys took place on Friday, October 17, 2025, and the article's publication date reflects the recent timing of the award announcement and its global significance.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2024 to 2025 marks the transition in the record for oldest Daytime Emmy winner, with Sir David Attenborough breaking Dick Van Dyke’s previous record in 2025, signaling a shift in age-based achievement in television awards.

keyTakeAways: Sir David Attenborough, at 99 years old, won the Daytime Emmy for Outstanding Daytime Personality, Non-Daily, becoming the oldest winner in the award's history.

His documentary 'Secret Lives of Orangutans' also won two additional awards: Outstanding Music Direction and Composition and Outstanding Directing Team for a Single Camera Daytime Non-Fiction Programme.
This achievement surpasses the previous record held by Dick Van Dyke, who won at age 98 in 2024.
The 52nd Annual Daytime Emmys were held in Pasadena, California, on Friday, October 17, 2025, though Sir David was not in attendance.
Sir David’s career spans over 70 years and includes iconic natural history programmes such as Life on Earth, The Private Life of Plants, and The Blue Planet.
He has inspired over 40 animal and plant species to be named after him, reflecting his global scientific and cultural influence.
His recent film 'Ocean' is described as a pivotal project in addressing biodiversity loss and climate change, reinforcing his ongoing role in environmental advocacy.
Other winners at the ceremony included 'General Hospital' for Outstanding Daytime Drama Series and Drew Barrymore for Outstanding Daytime Talk Series Host.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sir David Attenborough, aged 99, has become the oldest Daytime Emmy winner in history for his work on the Netflix documentary 'Secret Lives of Orangutans', winning in the Outstanding Daytime Personality, Non-Daily category. The documentary also earned two additional awards, highlighting its quality and impact. This achievement surpasses the previous record held by actor Dick Van Dyke, who won at age 98 in 2024. The 52nd Annual Daytime Emmys took place in Pasadena, California, though Attenborough was not present. His long-standing career in natural history broadcasting, including iconic programmes like 'Life on Earth' and 'The Blue Planet', underscores his global influence. His recent film 'Ocean' is described as a pivotal effort in combating climate change and protecting biodiversity, reinforcing his role as a leading environmental advocate.
title: Sir David Attenborough is oldest Daytime Emmy winner for Secret Lives of Orangutans
